title: Chemotherapy Risk Assessment Scale for High-Age Patients (CRASH) Score
description: Assesses the risk of severe chemotherapy toxicity in older cancer patients (≥70 years). Predicts both hematologic (grade 4) and nonhematologic (grade 3/4) toxicities based on patient characteristics and chemotherapy regimen.

parameters.name: iadl_score
parameters.description: Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score

result.name: crash_score
result.description: CRASH score with hematologic and nonhematologic subscores

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for severe chemotherapy toxicity. Approximately 7% risk of hematologic toxicity and 33% risk of nonhematologic toxicity.
Low-intermediate risk for severe chemotherapy toxicity. Approximately 23% risk of hematologic toxicity and 46% risk of nonhematologic toxicity.
Intermediate-high risk for severe chemotherapy toxicity. Approximately 54% risk of hematologic toxicity and 67% risk of nonhematologic toxicity.
High risk for severe chemotherapy toxicity. Approximately 100% risk of hematologic toxicity and 93% risk of nonhematologic toxicity. Consider dose reduction or alternative therapy.

references: Extermann M, Boler I, Reich RR, Lyman GH, Brown RH, DeFelice J, et al. Predicting the risk of chemotherapy toxicity in older patients: the Chemotherapy Risk Assessment Scale for High-Age Patients (CRASH) score. Cancer. 2012 Jul 1;118(13):3377-86.

Extermann M, Reich RR, Sehovic M. Chemotoxicity recalibration in the common terminology criteria for adverse events version 4.0 in older patients with cancer: Development of a training set. J Geriatr Oncol. 2013 Oct;4(4):353-8.
formula: CRASH Score = Hematologic Subscore + Nonhematologic Subscore (chemotherapy risk counted only once in combined score)
notes: Designed for patients aged ≥70 years starting chemotherapy
Hematologic toxicity defined as grade 4 per CTCAE v3.0
Nonhematologic toxicity defined as grade 3/4 per CTCAE v3.0
IADL score ranges from 0-29, higher scores indicate better function
Chemotherapy risk values are based on specific regimen toxicity profiles
